custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: This collection incorporates previously un-cataloged items and material from the dismantled vertical file on Henry Bromfield Pearson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection includes portraits, correspondence, a brief biography, and a photograph of the Pearson family.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Henry Bromfield Pearson was born on March 29, 1795 and died June 29, 1867. His father, Eliphalet Pearson LL.D. (1752-1826), was the first preceptor of Phillips Andover Academy and became a professor of Hebrew and oriental languages at Harvard. After attending Andover, Henry Bromfield Pearson entered Yale as a member of the class of 1815. He left Yale for Harvard, from which he graduated with a B.A. in 1816.

Being independently wealthy, Henry Bromfield Pearson designated Alonzo Ames Miner, then president of Tufts College, as the executor of his will. His original will stipulated the creation of a high school for girls. However, a codicil to the will made Tufts College a beneficiary of the Bromfield Pearson estate and allowed the College to interpret the will according to its own design. Consequently, in 1893 Tufts College established the Bromfield-Pearson High School, a co-educational, primarily technical school that existed until the 1960s. Yale University Library holds his and his family papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains portraits of members of the Pearson family, correspondence relating to Henry Bromfield Pearson's will, a biographical sketch of Henry Bromfield Pearson's, and a photograph of Bromfield-Pearson Hall. Also included is a wooden box encased in pliable (lead?) metal.
